Award.AwardTitle: Local Knowledge: An Anthropologist at Work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
More than any other attribute of cultural anthropology, ethnographic field research gives the discipline its unique identity and value. Anthropology's signature methodology, particularly participant observation, has been widely borrowed by other disciplines, yet there is often little understanding of what it actually entails. How do cultural anthropologists carry out their research? What exactly do they do in the field? Despite the centrality of fieldwork to the discipline of cultural anthropology, the conduits through which its findings are communicated do not always reach a larger audience. This project seeks to engage a wider audience with anthropological science by producing a documentary film on anthropological field work in North America.

The film highlights the value of local or indigenous knowledge in developing better landscape and environmental measures. Older ethnographic films once offered anthropology audiences an inside view of the kind of traditional fieldwork anthropologists did in tribal settings a half-century ago. The current film shows the continuing value of participant observation alongside new methods and their utility in myriad settings. This film will educate general audiences and students alike about what cultural anthropologists actually do today. The film promises to be a valuable resource for anthropology students and for scholars in other disciplines interested in contemporary anthropological research. It illustrates the main elements of field research: from moving into a foreign community, learning the language, clarifying one's role, and gaining rapport to living as closely as possible to the communities of study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Progress Report, August 8, 2020

 “Communicating Anthropological Science,”

George Gmelch

The completed film, “A Year in the Field: the Work of Anthropology” shows a young Estonian anthropologist Joonas Plaan at work studying local perceptions and impact of climate change in the remote fishery-dependent village of Bay de Verde, Newfoundland.   The film illustrates all the main elements of ethnographic fieldwork, from learning the language, finding a role in the community, and developing rapport to conducting participant observation, interviewing, participating in the daily life of the community and recording data in field notes. Joonas develops rapport with the local fishers by working alongside them in the crab and lobster fishery.  He discovers is a transformative experience for the individual who engages in it.

The film is being distributed by the Boston-based Documentary Educational Resources, the leading distributor of ethnographic films and media aimed at promoting cross-cultural understanding. It has also been shown a number of film festivals including the Helsinki International film Festival, the North Dakota Environmental Film Festival,  and the film festival of the Royal Anthropological Institute in the UK.  The film is now making its way into university classrooms where it is being used to illustrate the methods of cultural anthropology.
